title: Before 1 January 2020, will the registration deadline for Germany's ownership tax exemption for fully-electric vehicles be extended beyond 2020?
preds:
The legislation passed, but doesn't contain the ownership tax breaks, according to these reports (in German):
https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.rnd.de/politik/das-klimapaket-wer-wird-entlastet-wer-zahlt-drauf-EK7CNG5XK5CXVCFDMIQBXUV7I4.html%3foutputType=amp
https://amp.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article204477336/Klimaschutz-Bundesrat-stimmt-Kompromiss-zum-Klimapaket-zu.html
The intent is there, but its not clear that legislation is actually in place by year end. Lots written about subsidies in Nov, but no follow up since the VW announcement.
It will be Extended, but in 2020 (towards the end of 2020), not before. They normally don´t do things like that a year before it is relevant.

"The incentive will also be extended from the end of 2020 currently to the end of 2025." https://www.dailymail.co.uk/money/cars/article-7647951/Germany-hike-electric-car-subsidies-VW-launches-car.html
Electric cars will be so mainstream that regulations against ICE cars will be enforced instead.

The paper released after the "Climate Cabinet" on Friday has an extension of the ownership tax exemption until 2025 in it [1, p. 9] , along with the intention for the measures to take effect in 2019 [1, p. 21] . [1] https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/997532/1673502/768b67ba939c098c994b71c0b7d6e636/2019-09-20-klimaschutzprogramm-data.pdf?download=1 (in German)
Not quite zero but coming down markedly. Germany could still easily extend but I haven’t seen anything and not part of “climate cabinet”.

If nothing unveiled today, will be going to zero. Germany is behind in its commitments to 2020 and 2030 re climate change etc so has to do something. And it’s car manufacturers are ramping up electrics quickly,

Adjusting upwards because one of the ideas to be discussed at tomorrow's German "Climate Cabinet" meeting includes reforming vehicle ownership tax to depend on CO2 emissions of the vehicle (which could in fact mean an exemption for full EVs): 
https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/klimakabinett-die-knackpunkte-in-den-groko-verhandlungen-klimaschutz-a-1286716.html
https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/klimaschutz-union-legt-sich-auf-co2-zertifikate-handel-fest-a-1286386.html (both in German)
Believe it will happen but they may let it lapse and back date (like prior)

"Car tax exemption: For pure electric vehicles of all vehicle classes, an exemption from the motor vehicle tax is extended to ten years. The tax exemption will be granted on the first registration of such vehicles in the period from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2020."[1] [1] https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/suche/elektro-mobilitaet-1669548

This says a law extending a number of tax incentives and purchase premiums for electric vehicles is planned to be passed by the end of 2019, but it does not mention extending the ownership tax exemption:
 https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/aktuelles/steuerliche-anreize-e-autos-1653134 (in German) 
This blog post is more explicit about the ownership tax exemption not being among the programs being extended:
https://emobly.com/de/news/warum-das-neue-foerderprogramm-fuer-elektroautos-nicht-reicht/ (in German)  Leaving 20% probability in case the law gets amended or changed while passing through parliament.

Nothing new but will need to start ratcheting down if paucity of info
http://www.spiegel.de/wirtschaft/olaf-scholz-legt-eigenes-energiekonzept-vor-a-1261420.html
Leading the world on this technology
Momentum in favour of electric vehicles.  Slow take up to date requiring further government support.

- Automakers anti-EV lobbying efforts. Lobbying efforts seem to be quite strong in pushing back EV adoption at the moment.
- confused incentive program where customers might be asked to return the incentives after they've purchased create uncertainty for buyers.
- very slow adoption of EV compared to North America and rest of Europe (@100,000; only half of which seem to be fully electric; other half hybrid. This is compared to the 41 million cars on German roads as of Jan 2018)
- seem to target Tesla legally and politically, even though Tesla sales in Germany are miniscule. This promotes the sense of uncertainty and difficulty to the consumer. 
- EV start-ups springing up to fill big auto manufacturer void will be eaten -- too small to sustain a profit in such a capital intensive industry with high barriers to entry.
So slow adoption in Germany compared to other non-auto manufacturing economies as evidenced by pool of incentive susibsidies used as of August 2018 sat somewhere around 100,000 million euros out of 600, 000 million offered back in 2016.    Trends
 "Since the launch of the program in 2016, over 46 000 applications for plug-in vehicles subsidy were submitted.  Last year alone the EV sales in the country increased by  23%."  EVs are a transformational innovation; not a passing trend. Climate change iniatives seems to be central to economic policy. So it seems really stupid for one of world's best automaking countries to see it pass them by like this. (But stupid is everywhere these days.) Merkel's subsidy efforts might be better suited to incentivizing the manufacturers to push price of EVs and ancilliary items (like charging stations) down.  I think Chancellor Merkel's visionary leadership is coming to a close. Hard to tell if her successor will embrace EVs or bow to big auto manufacturers to secure short term political concession. There's no consumer rush to take a chunk of the 600,000 mill euros so lowering (as opposed to canning it altogether) is a political win..savings to the public purse but still says the country is committed to a move away from diesel.  Will this be extended by 2020 who knows? That's the arbitrary part but I don't see anything that says it won't be renewed (just not sure if it's in time for q deadline) https://www.fleetcarma.com/can-learn-germany-ev-adoption/

It seems to me that the focus is on providing incentives to purchase not tax cuts. They have until next year to extend the ownership tax, and you could argue that thinking it will go away might drive some purchases. https://www.reuters.com/article/electric-vehicles-germany-bonus-idUSL8N23651R

https://apnews.com/b7d3cdfa1a034b7a9433f29f63202cf0
Once again, some confusion about what a Q means, although I may be the only one who is confused on account of being superannuated.   Is "beyond 2020" after 31 December 2020, or after 1 January 2020, which would ordinarily be stated as "into 2020" or some such?  Presumably the former, since the current programme runs through 2020.  We'll see, I suppose.

Germany has consistently worked towards lowering their carbon emissions and mass use of electric vehicles certainly helps with that. If they have not reached their million electric vehicles on the road goal as of 2020 and are pushing to have an increase by 2022, then they will continue to want to incentivize ownership and use of electric vehicles. The tax exemption is a perfect incentive and I think there is an almost certain chance the German government will keep this policy beyond 2020.

German manufactures need German citizens to buy their EV's as they emerge this year and next. The German auto manufacturers managed to convince the authorities that diesel was a good idea. Extending EV's perks is child's play by comparison because it actually is.

- German government wants to reach 1m electric vehicles by 2022 (extended from 2020). Price still seems to be a challenge. [1]
- With current trends even that seems to be a stretch. Only 68k electric vehicles were registered last year, up from 54k the year before. [2] So there's still quite a lot to do in barely 3 years.
- There are numerous articles about Scholz wanting to extend the subsidy. [3][4][5]
- This law has been extended before. [6] All of this makes me quite confident that there will be an extension. [1] https://www.faz.net/aktuell/wirtschaft/diginomics/eine-million-elektroautos-bis-2022-kann-das-klappen-15795583.html
[2] https://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Elektroautos-68-000-Neuzulassungen-in-Deutschland-4249935.html
[3] https://ecomento.de/2019/04/08/finanzminister-will-steuerlichen-foerderung-der-e-mobilitaet-ausweiten/
[4] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-autos-electric/germany-to-extend-electric-company-car-tax-incentives-paper-idUSKCN1Q50JN
[5] https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/german-finance-minister-wants-extend-electric-car-incentives
[6] https://www.bmwi.de/Redaktion/DE/Artikel/Industrie/rahmenbedingungen-und-anreize-fuer-elektrofahrzeuge.html
Since Germany is committed to clean energy eco system ,it will push further with huge potentialities to become market leader and realisation of sustainability goals
The development is nowhere near ready so Germany will have no choice but to extend
Germany sees which way the wind is blowing and wants the early mover advantage.

There are still not many fully electric vehicles on the street. So there is a long way to go. It is a good incentive to not to have pay car ownership tax. It is quite normal way in Germany to persuade car buyers - you have to pay more tax for a car with a diesel engine, for a car with a bigger engine (in the past- I think it is chanced now), for a car with higher emissions values. And it is a good incentive for the car industry to engineer better fully-electric vehicules knowing there are more potential buyers.
They don't like being outdone by Norway.  They have adequate money.  They want to encourage and lead the industry.
Highly likely given the German government's current stance on global climate change.
Germany remains to be in support of green technologies.
The politics in Germany is shifting and they won't want to give up any tax revenue.
It seems like the logical follow up for this.

Consensus of 99%...but not aware of anything firm. Ministers have been discussing and VW making major shift toward electric. Incentives by state will be required given role of unions and lander in VW management.
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/03/12/vw-boosts-electric-production-by-50percent-with-22-million-bevs-by-2029.html
Staying with the curve on this.
Going up a couple points to stay above the consensus.

This looks like a wuestion of when, not if.  The only way I can see this being more of a done deal is if they needed a way of goosing auto purchases that dipped as part of a macro event in the larger economy.

Going a few points high to be ahead of the curve. Extending the tax exemption has two benefits to Germany that I believe makes this an easy question. First, extending the exemption helps German car companies to innovate by boosting buyers and second it helps Germany's transition to a cleaner economy.

1. The government has a target of 1 million cars by 2020 that won't be met.
2.The government is supportive of electric cars. German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz plans to extend tax incentives for electric company cars, he told a newspaper on Saturday, the government's latest attempt to boost demand for clean vehicles.
https://auto.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/industry/germany-to-extend-electric-company-car-tax-incentives/68032680

It is very likely, since the registration goals will probably not be met until 2020. Additionally there is a high pressure to decrease fine dust emission in cities. On top of that every new registered (German) car is good for the economy.

German manufacturers (Audi/Porsche/VW, BMW, Mercedes) all ramping up electrics in a big way... German government behind goal in adoption. Most Germans seem committed to alternatives and willing to fund. Germany is surrounded by countries with tax breaks for electrics and has no doubt taken notice of Norway where about one third of new cars are pure electric. Norway has extended their incentives despite exceeding take up objectives (acknowledging not all are happy about exemption for parking, tolls, and bus lanes however).
It would be a great ideal this is a ♻️Ideal
It is a goal too ambitious

This seems like a back door way around the EU POLICY OF DISCOURAGING AND LIMITING a state subsidy for a business. However the Auto Lobby is as powerful there as any lobby group here - so they may get away with extension.
I think it is quite a bit more likely than not.
